2102.00593.text: While the promise of AI in medicine is alluring, the use of these systems in healthcare has been discussed for decades, and yet few of these tools have resulted in successful implementation and use in clinical practice [41].
2102.00593.label: Novelty

2102.00593.text: One area of healthcare that researchers have expected to benefit from the implementation of DSTs, but has yet to adopt such technological support, is major depressive disorder (MDD).
2102.00593.label: Novelty

2102.00593.text: Antidepressant medications are a common form of treatment for MDD, but selecting an effective treatment for a patient is a complex task.
2102.00593.label: Novelty

2102.00593.text: 4) compare and contrast DST output with existing standards of care.
2102.00593.label: Novelty

2102.00593.text: We recommend that for time-constrained medical environments, we shift from designing explanations for every decision to on-demand explanations that contrast AI recommendations with current standards of care.
2102.00593.label: Novelty

2102.00593.text: While ML models for antidepressant treatment selection exist, these systems are rarely integrated into clinical practice due to low user acceptance and a failure to account for user expectations in the system design [19, 33].
2102.00593.label: Novelty

2102.00593.text: Notably, DSTs are typically not abandoned due to poor performance, but rather due to failures in accounting for the complexity of the healthcare sociotechnical system [51].
2102.00593.label: Novelty
2102.00593.section: 2 RELATEDWORK 2.2 Clinical Decision Support Tools: Healthcare

2102.00593.text: While we have seen many recent advances related to the use of HCI methods for designing AI tools, we have seen few studies that discuss what it will take to make these tools work within complex sociotechnical systems.
2102.00593.label: Novelty

2102.00593.text: Finding an effective antidepressant medication for someone diagnosed with MDD is an important but difficult task.
2102.00593.label: Novelty

2102.00593.text: However, primary care appointments last an average of only 20 minutes in the United States, and internationally primary care appointments can be as short as a few minutes [28].
2102.00593.label: Novelty

2102.00593.text: While these treatment guidelines provide a useful resource, the heterogeneity in patients symptoms and tolerability of antidepressants means that identifying an effective treatment for an individual remains a process of trial and error [65].
2102.00593.label: Novelty

2102.00593.text: We extend existing literature by identifying other aspects of the healthcare system that must be considered in the creation and deployment of novel DSTs.
2102.00593.label: Novelty

2102.00593.text: However, they also noted that new technology introduced into the clinic would require substantial validation through randomized controlled trials, supporting their trust in new tools.

2102.00593.text: While explaining black box models is a consistent theme in AI work, we need best practices for adapting the design of DSTs for timeconstrained environments.

2102.00593.section: 6 DISCUSSION 6.1 Creating multi-user systems for collaborative decision-making

2102.00593.text: While AI research continues to focus on improving information accuracy for clinicians, modern clinical care aspires toward shared decisionmaking with patients and clinicians working together to make decisions [12, 39].
2102.00593.label: Novelty
2102.00593.section: 6 DISCUSSION 6.1 Creating multi-user systems for collaborative decision-making

2102.00593.text: However, in high stakes or time critical environments, this process places time and mental burden on users.
2102.00593.label: Novelty

2102.00593.text: However, without the time to review an AI prediction or recommendation in detail, greater responsibility needs to be placed up front to determine when the system is likely to err, and when the tool should perhaps not be shown altogether.
2102.00593.label: Novelty

2102.00593.text: While explanations to support transparency at each decision point were seen as unhelpful in general, more details in the case of surprising predictions were viewed more favorably.
2102.00593.label: Novelty

2102.00593.text: We do not yet have established best practices for dealing with contrasting information, but helping clinicians identify the best way to proceed is critical.

2102.00593.text: We posit that by making these aspects of healthcare central to the design of DSTs, we may develop tools that are capable of supporting the collaborative nature of healthcare, identifying potential adverse events caused by ML predictions, working within time-critical environments, and recognizing conflicting information.
2102.00593.label: Novelty

2102.00593.text: While we see this as an important first step, next-step studies should engage with other stakeholders, such as patients, nurses, pharmacists, and therapists.

2102.00593.text: In medicine, the integration of AI tools could lead to a substantial paradigm shift in which human-AI collaboration becomes integrated in medical decision-making.
2102.00593.label: Conclusion

2102.00593.text: Such AI-powered decision support tools (DSTs) may support many clinical practices, including diagnosing illnesses, selecting the optimal treatment for a patient, and predicting disease trajectories [72].
2102.00593.label: Conclusion

2102.00593.text: One area of healthcare that researchers have expected to benefit from the implementation of DSTs, but has yet to adopt such technological support, is major depressive disorder (MDD).
2102.00593.label: Conclusion

2102.00593.text: The majority of mental health care is initiated in primary care settings, yet the extent of training primary care providers (PCP) receive in managing MDD can vary widely [63, 69], and contemporary treatment guidelines provide little support in choosing among them [31].
2102.00593.label: Conclusion

2102.00593.text: CHI 21, May 813, 2021, Yokohama, Japan
2102.00593.label: Conclusion

2102.00593.text: We found that intelligent decision support tools will need to seamlessly integrate into clinicians time constrained workflows, which typically involve short appointments with patients to understand their symptoms and make treatment decisions.
2102.00593.label: Conclusion

2102.00593.text: Decision support tools are computational systems created to facilitate medical decision-making [47].
2102.00593.label: Conclusion
2102.00593.section: 2 RELATEDWORK 2.2 Clinical Decision Support Tools: Healthcare

2102.00593.text: Sociotechnical approaches have been important in healthcare for understanding how new technologies may be effectively integrated into the social processes that make up healthcare work [7].
2102.00593.label: Conclusion

2102.00593.text: Therefore, motivated by Bergs sociotechnical approach, which highlights the importance of empirical research of healthcare practices in which the technology will be used [6], we consider the social, technical, and organizational issues that must be considered in the design of DSTs for MDD treatment selection.
2102.00593.label: Conclusion

2102.00593.text: studies focused on creating ML models to support MDD treatment decisions [25, 49, 57].
2102.00593.label: Conclusion

2102.00593.text: To support treatment selection, the Canadian Network for Mood and Anxiety Treatments provides widely followed treatment guidelines for 25 antidepressants, organized as first-, second-, and (a small number of) third-line treatments [31].
2102.00593.label: Conclusion

2102.00593.text: If ineffective, the provider may try secondand then third-line treatment, which often have more severe side effects or drug interactions.
2102.00593.label: Conclusion

2102.00593.text: To facilitate future-state ideation, we designed low fidelity prototypes to demonstrate a variety of features and information we could potentially derive based on existing ML research that uses electronic medical record data.
2102.00593.label: Conclusion

2102.00593.text: These studies collectively provide insights into how DSTs may be better situated into clinical routines.
2102.00593.label: Conclusion

2102.00593.text: In this paper, we report on aspects of the healthcare sociotechnical system that should be considered in the design of machine learning decision support tools.

2104.04842.text: Second, we chose metrics to measure both a chatbots abilities to complete an interview task effectively ( elicitation abilities ) and a users experience with the chatbot ( user experience ) because an ideal interview chatbot should be able to complete interview tasks while delivering a satisfactory user experience.
2104.04842.label: Novelty

2104.04842.text: For example, the metric informativeness measures the amount of information conveyed by user responses to each interview question, while the metric user sentiment measures a users overall interview experience with a chatbot.
2104.04842.label: Novelty

2104.04842.text: This is to ensure specific design suggestions can be generated to help designers improve a chatbot question by question (locally), while providing designers with an assessment of the overall interview experience (globally).
2104.04842.label: Novelty

2104.04842.text: While response quality directly assesses the quality of user responses to an interview question, the level of user engagement quantifies how much a participant is engaged with a chatbot from multiple aspects (e.g., how long an engagement is).

2104.04842.label: Method

2104.04842.text: Since our formative study indicated that chatbot designers wish to obtain certain quantitative feedback on the performance of their existing chatbot (T1), we first formulated a computational framework that quantitatively measures the effectiveness of such an interview chatbot from multiple aspects.
2104.04842.label: Method

2104.04842.text: To present a generated chatbot profile, design suggestions, and relevant conversation evidence, we used Tableau [57] to implement a web-based, interactive visual dashboard (Fig 1).
2104.04842.label: Method

2104.04842.text: Using the same set of interview questions about COVID-19 shown in Table 1, we first built an interview chatbot on Juji using only Jujis built-in features without making any customization.
2104.04842.label: Method

2104.04842.text: Given an interview question (e.g., where are you located ) and a performance metric (e.g., repetition rate ), iChatProfile first selects all conversation segments (Fig 4(b)) that produced a metric score worse than the threshold.
2104.04842.label: Method

2104.04842.text: After asking all the interview questions, the chatbot also included questions to elicit user satisfaction rating and trust rating, as well as their rationale behind each rating.
2104.04842.label: Method

2104.04842.text: Currently, we use the Vader model [16] to perform sentimental analysis on the collected users responses, and compute the percentages of positive, neutral and negative responses.
2104.04842.label: Method

2104.04842.text: It states that if the computed repetition rate for an interview question ( Q ) is above a certain threshold, it then uses a template to generate a set of design suggestions that could reduce repetitions and improve user experience.
2104.04842.label: Method
